Result.Abstract: Instructional strategies and curriculum sequences aimed at teaching process skills have received considerable attention in science education. On the other hand, the teaching of domain-independent, context-free skills has been subject to criticism on the ground that important aspects of cognitive activities are functions of meaningful contexts. The intent of this study was to examine the development of integrated process skills
Result.Title: The development of science process skills in authentic contexts

Result.Abstract: Classrooms are complex environments in which curriculum, students, and teachers interact. The purpose of this study was to document students' epistemologies and their concurrent views about knowing
Result.Title: Physics students' epistemologies and views about knowing and learning

Result.Title: "Vygotsky's Neglected Legacy": Cultural-Historical Activity Theory

Result.Title: The concept map as a tool for the collaborative construction of knowledge: A microanalysis of high school physics students

Result.Title: Science education as/for participation in the community

Result.Abstract: Although laboratory activities have long been recognized for their potential to facilitate the learning of science concepts and skills, this potential has yet to be realized. Result.Title: Experimenting in a constructivist high school physics laboratory

Result.Title: Curriculum-Based Ecosystems: Supporting Knowing From an Ecological Perspective

Result.Abstract: There is a lack of studies that sharply focus on what students are actually doing in science laboratories. Result.Title: The local production of order in traditional science laboratories: A phenomenological analysis

Result.Abstract: Teaching in urban schools, with their problems of violence, lack of resources, and inadequate funding, is difficult. It is even more difficult to learn to teach in urban schools. Result.Title: Learning to teach science in urban schools

Result.Title: Professionals Read Graphs: A Semiotic Analysis

Result.Title: From activity to gestures and scientific language

Result.Title: What Good Is Polarizing Research Into Qualitative and Quantitative?

Result.Title: Fostering conceptual change by analogies—between Scylla and Charybdis

Result.Title: Learning science through technological design

Result.Title: Becoming-in-the-classroom: a case study of teacher development through coteaching

Result.Title: Prevalence, function, and structure of photographs in high school biology textbooks

Result.Title: Affordances of computers in teacher-student interactions: The case of interactive physicsTM

Result.Title: The co-evolution of situated language and physics knowing

Result.Abstract: During their training, future teachers usually learn the subject matter of science. However, they are largely left on their own when it comes to figuring out how to teach this subject matter, that is, how to find appropriate pedagogical forms. Result.Title: Lessons on and from the dihybrid cross: An activity-theoretical study of learning in coteaching

Result.Abstract: In this article, we propose coteaching as a viable model for teacher preparation. Coteaching, working at the elbows of someone else, allows beginning teachers to experience appropriate action at the right time. Coteaching provides beginning teachers with shared experiences that become the topic of their professional conversations with other coteachers (including peers, cooperating teacher, and university supervisors). We articulate our
Result.Title: Learning to teach science as practice

Result.Title: From gesture to scientific language

Result.Title: Inventors, copycats, and everyone else: The emergence of shared resources and practices as defining aspects of classroom communities

Result.Title: Science, culture, and the emergence of language

Result.Title: Knowing What You Tell, Telling What You Know: Uncertainty and Asymmetries of Meaning in Interpreting Graphical Data

Result.Abstract: Past educational improvement endeavors were fundamentally centered on the learner as an individual. Result.Title: Contradictions in theorizing and implementing communities in education

Result.Abstract: In some contexts, a photograph may be worth a thousand words. Result.Title: Making sense of photographs

Result.Title: Coordination in coteaching: Producing alignment in real time

Result.Abstract: Gestures are pervasive in human communication across cultures; they clearly constitute an embodied aspect of cognition. Result.Title: From action to discourse: The bridging function of gestures

Result.Abstract: Graphing-related activities are notoriously difficult for students of science. In this article, we examine cognitive complexities when graphs are used in lectures. Result.Title: Complexities of graphical representations during ecology lectures: an analysis rooted in semiotics and hermeneutic phenomenology

Result.Title: Interpreting unfamiliar graphs: A generative, activity theoretic model

Result.Title: Emergence, flexibility, and stabilization of language in a physics classroom

Result.Title: The nature of scientific conceptions: A discursive psychological perspective

Result.Title: Science and the “Good Citizen”: Community-Based Scientific Literacy

Result.Title: The Implications of Coteaching/Cogenerative Dialogue for Teacher Evaluation: Learning from Multiple Perspectives of Everyday Practice

Result.Title: Learning Environments Research, Lifeworld Analysis, and Solidarity in Practice

Result.Title: Situated cognition and assessment of competence in science

Result.Title: Decalages in Talk and Gesture: Visual and Verbal Semiotics of Ecology Lectures

Result.Title: Those Who Get Hurt aren’t Always Being Heard: Scientist-Resident Interactions over Community Water

Result.Title: What is the meaning of “meaning”? A case study from graphing

Result.Title: Coteaching/Cogenerative Dialoguing: Learning Environments Research as Classroom Praxis

Result.Title: The nature of scientific knowledge and student learning: Two longitudinal case studies

Result.Title: Bodily experience and mathematical conceptions: from classical views to a phenomenological reconceptualization
